displayed_text: Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Here I’m happy to say the product is definitely of high grade. Uh, but you’ve got to give it two days out of every week. Okay? So logistically that means as long as they are given twenty-four hours apart, you can just come up once, and the study pays for you to stay overnight at a hotel. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay? But that’s weekly. Patient: Okay, well I - Doctor: So like you’ll come up. You’ll get the one day where you get the chemo and the vitamin C. The next day 24 hours later you get vitamin C and you can go home. Patient: Oh well- Doctor: And the same next week, same thing. So you always stay overnight at a hotel. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: But they’ll cover that cost. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Yeah.

Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Um and then but so it’s nothing more than the usual. Patient: Okay. Doctor: And then we have a point six percent of a seizure. So less than one percent of folks who normally have heavy alcohol intake. Patient: I don’t drink. Doctor: Right, so we give the stuff a lot in this clinic. Patient: Let me ask you this here. Doctor: Mm, hmm. Patient: What is the effects of a seizure? Doctor: Well a seizure is exactly what you see on TV you know when your brain is too hyperactive and you’re kind of going like this and you can’t control it. Patient: Okay so what do we do? And the reason why… Doctor: If that happens she’s calling nine one one, but it’s a percent chance less than that. Okay. Patient: Okay then let me ask you this here doc. Let me ask you this here. If I had a seizure

Doctor: And what are you missin’ out on? Doctor: So you’re not – (housework) Patient: Yeah. Chores. (Pause) Doctor: But it gets done the next day or next – or you get it done eventually – or? Patient: Eventually. Laying kitchen floor right now. Doctor: Have you had any falls? Patient: No. Doctor: And you take naps? Doctor: Once a day or once – Patient: Once a day. In the afternoon. Four or five o’clock. Doctor: Where do you hurt these days? Patient: No. Doctor: No pain? No discomfort?

Patient: He might have been a Norman. Doctor: He might have been! Patient: Which would be worse than anything. Doctor: Maybe they were, yeah. I don’t know. No, I think, that’s French, right? Patient: Yeah. Doctor: No, I don’t have any French. Doctor: I had some Spanish-Portuguese, maybe Doctor: One of my grand, great-grandmothers had a little thing on the side. I don’t know. Doctor: Yeah, the joke is uh – Patient: He used to say that all the time, yeah. Doctor: Mommy’s baby, daddy’s maybe. Is that what I’ve heard? (Laughs) Family Member: It’s twenty-three and me --- Doctor: One of them tells you like how much Neanderthal you have. Ancestry didn’t tell you that.

Patient: and something like that too, but nothing that I’ve had right now and I, I, I I’m not consistent with it. Doctor: Sure. Patient: It’s just something that we’ve tried – Doctor: Right. Patient: - been recommended that we try and I think we brought it up but… Doctor: Yeah. You know cancer is cancer, it’s got its own set of pain. Patient: Well and… Doctor: Here’s the thing you got to take the medication. Patient: You want me to start to take a look at the Norco again or? Doctor: I think you should and just don’t let it get out of control you know, like I’d rather you take it occasionally or all the time if you need to. There’s no right or wrong on that. Family Member: It’s not that bad. Patient: I’m not that bad but there is a lot of inconsistency though.

Family Member: Oh yeah. Patient: So anyway back to the problem. Doctor: Yeah. Patient: Your husband did what he does. Doctor: Yeah. Patient: And so this is gonna show us if if it worked? Doctor: Yeah so the CAT scan I think one of our concerns was that you also had the lymph node disease. Patient: Right. Yeah. Doctor: And at the last time that we did it before we started the Xofigo, really the lymph nodes were not a part of the problem. Okay. So assuming that the lymph nodes are still well controlled and everything, then I don’t think we need to do any further treatment. We’re sort of in watch and wait monitor mode. Patient: Right. Doctor: If, however, the lymph nodes are growing or other areas that non-bone disease is showing progression, then we’ve got to address it. Patient: Start chemo or…

Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.

About how long has it been since you las.Within the last 2 years (1 year but less: About how long has it been since you last saw a doctor or other health professional about your health?:::Within the last 2 years (1 year but less than 2 years ago)

During the past 12 months, not counting.1 time: During the past 12 months, not counting times you went to an emergency room, how many times did you go to a doctor, nurse, or other health professional to get care for yourself?:::1 time

Sometimes doctors care more about what i.strongly agree: Sometimes doctors care more about what is convenient for them than about their patients' medical needs.:::strongly agree

Doctors are extremely thorough and caref.neutral: Doctors are extremely thorough and careful.:::neutral

You completely trust doctors' decisions.disagree: You completely trust doctors' decisions about which medical treatments are best.:::disagree

A doctor would never mislead you about a.disagree: A doctor would never mislead you about anything.:::disagree

All in all, you trust doctors completely.disagree: All in all, you trust doctors completely.:::disagree

People of my ethnic group receive the sa.neutral: People of my ethnic group receive the same medical care from doctors and healthcare workers as people from other groups:::neutral

People of my ethnic group are treated th.disagree: People of my ethnic group are treated the same as people of other groups by doctors and healthcare workers:::disagree

Doctors have the best interests of peopl.neutral: Doctors have the best interests of people of my ethnic group in mind:::neutral

Which of the following best describe you.Unemployed for less than 1 year: Which of the following best describe your current occupational status? Mark all that apply.:::Unemployed for less than 1 year

What is the highest grade or level of s.College graduate: What is the highest grade or level of schooling you completed?:::College graduate

Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or.No, not Hispanic or Latino: Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or descent?:::No, not Hispanic or Latino

What race or races do you consider yours.Asian: What race or races do you consider yourself to be?:::Asian

displayed_text: Patient: If the PSA is that reliable in terms of – Doctor: Ehhh, it’s reliable enough. I don’t know, it’s not unbelievably reliable, but Patient: But, if – Doctor: Rather than, you know, trying to give you a CAT scan every month. Patient: It’s, it’s, it’s unlikely that the PSA is going to go up if things are okay. Doctor: Yes. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: That’s a reasonable ---- Family Member: But it wouldn’t stay down if things weren’t okay --- if you were getting worse, either. I mean, is there a false – Doctor: I mean, occasionally we have a patient where all the disease is getting better, and then one spot starts to grow. That’s where, that would be the one place we kind of fall through the cracks. But, usually, - the PSA represents the sum of all of the cancers in your body are contributing to it. So, usually, when it’s going down, we sort of think that the sum is going down. And, when it’s going up, we think that it’s starting to be resistant. Um. Family Member: Yeah. Patient: Okay.

Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: And it’s creeping up, so about three or four months ago twice in the thirties. The normal testosterone for a man of your age would be around a hundred and fifty or two hundred. When we checked your last blood test about two weeks ago it had gone up to fifty-eight. Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: So it’s slowly increasing. Patient: Right. Doctor: That would mean at least in theory that your fatigue should begin to get better, although the increase has been very recent, so it may not have given your body the time to adjust to that higher level of testosterone. And with time if you remain off of the hormone therapy like you’re currently doing despite your age it may continue to increase further. Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: So my hope is that with time the fatigue will get better. Patient: Is that a good thing because the testosterone feeds cancer, right? Doctor: Well, it’s a good thing and a bad thing. It’s a double-edged sword. Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: But you and I made the decision when we first met after a discussion with Dr.__ as well – Dr. – Patient: Uh huh.

Family Member: Well what is the something? Doctor: Something is an oral medication. It’s a new oral hormonal therapy. Patient: Okay. Doctor: It’s a second hormone therapy that given in connection with the injection of hormone therapy we believe may produce better outcomes than just injecting the hormone by itself. Patient: But even with that, that’s still just to slow it down; it’s not to cure anything. It’s kind of take it to add a little bit more Doctor: That’s correct. Everything that we have discussed today frankly is not really curative in terms of its potential. Patient: Okay. Family Member: Because there isn’t any. Doctor: Right. Patient: Okay, And um, now with that, and I guess we can talk about it when we decide what we’re going to do. Does that involve a placebo? Doctor: Uhm. Patient: If that involves a placebo – Doctor: One of the two trials. The hormone therapy trial does involve a placebo. The other one does not. The radiotherapy trial does not.

Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: you know and then that’s the information that says okay, what do we do next? Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: You know say I don’t like any of those trials that (names person) Family Member: Mm, hmm. Patient: Yeah, well I’m in favor of the trials. Family Member: There are a lot more side effects with the trials. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: I’m not sure there’s more side effects; it’s just sort of we just have to put them out there, talk about them more. Patient: Yes. Doctor: You know chemotherapy has its own set of side effects Patient: Right. Doctor: But we have what the known benefits potentially are, whereas the clinical trials—we don’t know the benefits.

Patient: What kind of breathing machine? Doctor: Uh. A ventilator. On TV. Those are television. Your body’s gotten so sick that if I get you to wake up, you still have the bad cancer. Patient: Oh. Doctor: Okay? So, I also, I mean, I’m not so sure we should be pounding on your chest. Uh, you should be thinking about how far will we go even if it looks bad. (Pause) Patient: No. See, my dad died from prostate cancer in nineteen eighty six. He hadn’t -- didn’t have much treatment at all. Uh. Family Member: He waited, he waited to have severe symptoms. Then he went and then (they’s found) Patient: So, um, you know, I’m concerned for my son. My brother. Uh. He might have something too. I mean, if I try somethin’, it will help ‘em. Doctor: Yeah. I mean, so this may not help you, but it may help us learn how to treat other men in the future. Uh. So, that is, you know, just you being a good citizen and helping that out and a hero, but that – you have to feel comfortable with that, you know, ‘cuz it could help. It may not help. If it does help, it may help others. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Um. And yet it’s your time. It’s your coming in here. Some of it’s your expense. You know, this drug enzalutamide, I don’t know what you were paying when you were on it before. Uh. It’s pretty expensive. It’s about ten thousand bucks a month. Um. And again, you would be taking it, even though we don’t think it’s gonna work ‘cuz -- because we think that it may make the immune therapy work better. So, we have to have people on it. Their PSA’s gonna be rising. Their ARV seven still has to be positive. (Laughs) Patient: Okay. I didn’t pay much for the Xtandi before. Uh, some kind of study from manufacturers – Doctor: Oh, so you had a study, or they had a, uh, a program that sort of reduced your cost?

Patient: No, we got one last uh two weeks. Doctor: So, we’ll figure out when your next one is and you’ll come back for that for sure Patient: Okay. Doctor: and then just know you can call anytime and come back in between. Patient: Okay. Alright. Doctor: And then the chemo we’ll just push back but just know it’s around. Patient: That’s right. Doctor: But who knows what will get developed in the meantime. Patient: Exactly, okay, alright. Doctor: Good, yeah. Patient: Um, about how long do you think this will take for them to… Doctor: To get going?

Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: Now, the survival part’s tricky because that’s the whole group, and some of the men, so, you look at the number total, it’s only, you know, a couple of months’ difference between the guys that get the drug and the guys that don’t. But within that group, there are some people that respond really well and really long who probably are getting much more than a couple of months, and there’s some people where it doesn’t do anything, and they’re probably getting nothing out of it. So, uh, the other thing they look at in the trials is something called a, sort of a risk reduction. So there’s pretty significant reduction in dying from prostate cancer if you’re on, if you take the drug. So in my experience, what I’ve seen is about a third of the men I give the drug to, their PSA drops, and they have a really long response that usually long means somewhere between, well, I’ve only been using it, you know, a couple of years now, but two to three years sometimes. Family Member: Um hum. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: One, one to three years, maybe, let’s say. Uh, another third of the guys, the PSA drops really nicely, and then starts to go back up usually six months or so, and then the third group of guys, usually the PSA is a readout. It just marches along. In your case, that’s going to be the primary thing for us because the bone, like I said, it’s hard to measure changes. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: So, uh, and the, the biggest fact from the drug was in men before chemotherapy, it’s probably just because they were earlier in their disease- Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Not, not that there was anything different before or after. So, uh, the two drugs, about sixty plus percent of men respond overall. So that’s what I said. About two-thirds of the guys respond, and then one-third seems to have a long response, and one-third has a shorter response, and one-third don’t. Uh, in terms of how to pick which one of those two. Uh, for a while, I, I was picking Zytiga instead of Xtandi. Zytiga, the one complication with Zytiga, is you have to take a small dose of prednisone with it, uh, to kind of counterbalance how Zytiga works. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Uh, the one reason we would do that is because we had some trials, uh, that were after Zytiga. But the other reason was a tendency of less fatigue with the Zytiga than the Xtandi, in my experience. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Both drugs can cause fatigue. But it seems to be more common and often a little bit worse with Xtandi. So, uh, in my choosing those two, I have been choosing Zytiga, just for that reason. Uh, but the Xtandi is a little bit easier, because you just have to take Xtandi. You don’t have to take another drug.

Patient: Okay. Doctor: if we can just contain it. Now, sometimes people just take it twice a day, kind of like before bed for sure so you sleep well Patient: Right. Doctor: and then when you’re kind of up and running whether it’s after breakfast and you’re like I’m gonna get as much stuff as I can done and I’m just gonna relax and wait for my next dose. Some of my guys have to take it three times a day and some of my guys are just like I’m okay, I can stand this stuff, it’s doable but at night I just can’t sleep. It’s just there all the time the achiness and pain. Patient: Right. Doctor: and they take it at night. However you do it just know it will constipate you. Patient: I know that, yes. Doctor: And you know that’s just a miserable status Patient: Yes. Yes. Doctor: to be in so we have to have you take over-the-counter um stool softeners, MiraLAX, so kind of almost like oh, I took two of these I maybe have to see where my poop situation is, Patient: Right. Doctor: I might need to take MiraLAX twice or I might have to add MiraLAX to Senokot or you go down the poop aisle at Rite Aid or CVS Patient: Right.

Patient: All of whom. All of whom. All eight, including the, the black guy who did this study from Harvard, were convinced that they had Native American, uh, genes. None. (Laughs) Doctor: Well, you know, I, I did this myself. Ancest--I did Ancestry. Patient: Yeah. I might do that. Doctor: And, uh, I don’t know what they. I don’t know enough about what they use as a marker to say you’re --- Patient: Yeah, x-y-or z. Doctor: I want to say, I think Native American, there’s certain mutations that might come up that are only in Native American population. So, anyway, my, my story was my, my name is D_. My, there’s a town in England called D_. I had done my genealogy back to eighteen twenty. Until, you know, my --- two generations ago came to America, multiple generations lived in England. Patient: Do you know that for sure? Doctor: Were married to people in England, had children in England. So, I’m English, right? And, then, my moth --- my grandmother’s German. My grandfather is English. So I’m going to do my Ancestry.com just to confirm, um, you know, those are my things. Family Member: I betcha you’re German, like us, yeah. Doctor: No English. I don’t even know how it’s possible because Doctor: It came back, like, I was German. My mother is Italian. That was there. The German was there, but it didn’t even mention English. And then, there was a little note, saying, “A low probability, four percent, English.” Like, no, that’s impossible because, English, English, English, English. Doctor: I see all of this, and I’m like, hmmm, I wonder if one of my great grandfathers is not English. (Laughs) Patient: He might have been a Norman.
